Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Cardioprotective Effects of Ginsenosides Against Anthracycline-Induced Cardiotoxicity

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of ginsenosides in preventing AIC.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were undergoing anthracycline treatment and met specific inclusion criteria. The study was conducted in a clinical setting.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either ginsenosides or a placebo.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of ginsenosides in preventing AIC.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) over six months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in the ginsenoside group and 100 in the placebo group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the ginsenoside group and 97 in the placebo group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The ginsenoside group showed a significant improvement in LVEF compared to placebo (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the ginsenoside group and 1% in the placebo group experiencing gastrointestinal side effects.

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by [source of funding].
